title: Goofs and Saddles
descriptions:
Set in the rambunctious Old West, Goofs and Saddles (1937) follows a trio of well-meaning but hapless cowboys tasked with thwarting a ruthless gang terrorizing a frontier town. The trio—cheerful leader who fancies himself a master strategist, a lanky, scatterbrained sidekick, and a stout, blustering pal with more bravado than sense—are deputized after a bungled barroom scuffle accidentally exposes the outlaws’ latest scheme. Charged with tracking the gang to their hidden camp, they set off across dusty trails, armed with mismatched gear, a dubious map, and their own chaotic ingenuity.

Their pursuit is a chain reaction of comic missteps: mistaken identities at a stage stop, a botched ambush that turns into an impromptu cattle drive, and gadget-laden “cowboy improvements” that backfire at the worst possible moment. Along the way, they befriend a sharp-witted saloon singer who feeds them clues and a kindly blacksmith who equips them with slapdash contraptions, from spring-loaded saddles to a booby-trapped chuck wagon.

When the outlaws kidnap the town’s express agent to force open a safe holding a payroll, the trio mounts a rescue that blends accidental brilliance with sheer luck. A chaotic chase erupts through canyons and scrubland, with runaway horses, collapsing fences, and a wagon wheel that stubbornly refuses to stay attached. Cornered at an abandoned corral, the heroes improvise a series of pratfall-laden traps, turning the terrain—and their own blunders—into unlikely advantages.

In the end, the gang is captured more by the trio’s unpredictable antics than by any clear plan. The grateful townsfolk celebrate, though the heroes’ victory speech is interrupted by a final, spectacular mix-up that sends them tumbling into a horse trough. Goofs and Saddles revels in slapstick western parody, where friendship, persistence, and comic chaos prove just enough to outwit hardened desperadoes.
